reviews.title: Thin Building
text: Something special on my way to St Lawrence Market is very interesting. The building is like a very long triangle, one end very thin then is bigger towards the other end next to the park. Fantastic looking outside staircase just like what you see in films.

reviews.title: MAXIMIZING CIVIC SPACE
text: Red brick has been put to good use in this Gothic Revival building. Known as 'the Flatiron', it perfectly fits the meeting point of Front/Wellington/Church Streets. On the back of the building is a fine mural by Derek Besarnt showing the nearby Perkins Block at 41-43 Front Street West.

reviews.title: Historic Toronto building
text: The Gooderham Building, also known as the Flatiron Building, is an historic office building at 49 Wellington Street East in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. It is located on the eastern edge of the city's Financial District (east of Yonge Street) in the St. Lawrence neighbourhood, wedged between Front Street and Wellington Street in Downtown Toronto, where they join up to form a triangular intersection. Unless you are going to the market I wouldn't go out of my way to visit.

reviews.title: Gooderham Building, Toronto, Canada
text: It's one of the iconic views in Toronto. I saw this building every day when I was in Trono :) You should visit here both in the morning and at night.

reviews.title: Good view
text: This building is so iconic!! It is so gorgeous the view! You can take good pictures of all the sides! It is free and in front of the building, you can read a little bit about the building. Near it, there is a park and St Lawrence Market

reviews.title: Good example of a flatiron building
text: If you've not seen a flatiron building, then this is a good example. It's an attractive building, of historic significance, and a Toronto landmark. There's a good view from Front Street East, standing on the centre island between the two traffic lanes. There is a plaque sharing information about the building too.

reviews.title: Unique
text: Unique. The shape of the building is so unique and I immediately understood the nickname of the building, flat iron. It is very close to st. Lawrence market, so it is worth visiting if you are heading to the neighborhood.

reviews.title: So unique
text: We really liked the place, in the middle if a busy Street, here was this awesome building with a unique shape to it. Makes for great photos too

reviews.title: An old remnant in the midst of modern Toronto
text: With the city's modern skyscrapers, this 1892 structure stands out for its old looks and modest proportion. It's an architectural icon in Old Toronto and reminds you of how the city must have looked like during those days. It's definitely worth a quick visit. Very instagrammable. ðŸ˜€

reviews.title: Strange
text: This was weirdly interesting. I googled the history of why this building is how it is and learned a few things. A noteworthy site.

reviews.title: Very unique building in the Heart of Toronto
text: Visiting St. Lawrence Market, you see this unique structure standing out.  Office building with history and ground level stores/bar. Old Gothic looking fitting into the new neighbourhood with flavour and also Flatiron Firkin Bar.

reviews.title: Beautiful unique building
text: This is a unique and beautiful building in the centre of the city, an historic office building that can be seen from different angles.

reviews.title: Beautiful Building If You're Nearby
text: The Flatiron is beautiful and worth walking by if you're nearby. It's less than 2 blocks from St. Lawrence Market. Second Cup coffee is across the street--you can grab a cup of coffee and see the building from the seats by the window.

reviews.title: Nothing Special
text: I came here on a Saturday afternoon after visiting the nearby St Lawrence Market. The building was interesting from the outside but that was it. I donâ€™t believe that the public could actually enter the building. There was a small coffee shop in its basement. Not worth visiting in my opinion.

reviews.title: Toronto vintage
text: Do walk to the Flatiron building in Toronto. This is a cool building and it doesn't get anymore classic Toronto than this.

reviews.title: Amazing!!!
text: Interesting place! You can take great photos in there! Near to a local market with fresh food and great products.

reviews.title: Unique
text: Beautiful and unique building in the middle of a street. Nice to see this kind of architecture in the city.

reviews.title: Past Meets Present
text: In a City that does not preserve heritage as  prime goal, the view of the Gooderham building is an interesting contrast with Toronto's modern skyline.  located at Front and Church is is easily accessible on any downtown walk with good restaurants in side and close around. For dog lovers, check out the statute behind the building. For urban art lovers see the mural at the rear of the builing. For history buffs continue to the distillery district.

reviews.title: Great photo opportunity
text: I took my husband and out of town friends there early September.

There happened to be a Shakespeare play in the triangle in front of the back side of the flat iron building in front of the tromphe loil mural.  Berczy park where the flat iron building sits, was reopened this summer for the 150th birthday of Canada. The patterned sidewalk and the crown jewel fountain in the middle offers photo oppportunies. The fountain with the sculptures of dogs and two cats is whimsical and classical at the same time.
Well with seeing.

reviews.title: Must walk by
text: Just a block walk from the St Lawrence Market this is a must do walk by. A piece of Old Toronto surrounded by high rise structures. Iconic.

reviews.title: Good visit to iconic building
text: Visited here with my wife while on tour to the east coast of Canada and loved the look at this iconic building and we also visited the cafeteria where we had coffee

reviews.title: Unique Historic Property
text: The Gooderham building is a heritage structure built in 1892 of red brick, with attractive arched windows and a copper roof in a unique pie shape due to the confluence of Wellington and Front streets. Built as the headquarters for the Gooderham family distillery business, it now serves as office space and downstairs houses the The Flatiron & Firkin pub. Looking from the front of the building, you get the old and the new with a  great view of new Toronto and it's skyline. The wide end of the building  backs up to quirky Berczy Park and has an impressive murial of windows that seem to be flutterting in the wind.

reviews.title: Unique
text: The Gooderham Building is easy to spot and is a unique landmark in Toronto.It resembles the Flatiron Building in New York but on a smaller scale.

reviews.title: Nice part of town
text: Really nice part of town, initially expected similar to the Flatiron in NYC but noting like it, smaller building, well kept and overlooking a lovely little doggie park

reviews.title: Nice place to relax
text: Especially small Park with funny fountain recommendable to sit down with a cup of coffee and pause for a while. Fountain is a hommage for the dog-loving canadians.

reviews.title: A nice landmark in good condition
text: Beautiful building, easy to spot. If you are driving it will only take amoment, might as well see it, short and easy. If you have a nice day, and are walking, stop and have a pint and an your next stop, there is much to do quite close by.

reviews.title: Lovely building
text: Stumbled into this building by accident while we were just roaming around blindly
Love its architect and artwork behind it. Very eye catching
Remember to walk behind the building. Think people tend to forget
Worthwhile a stop

reviews.title: Beautiful Building
text: A similar building to New York's perhaps better known structure but equally stunning.
Artisan craftsmanship and Architectural design at it's best.
Lovely building.
Remember to go look at the mural at the back of the building.

reviews.title: Superb Building
text: The Flatiron building is quite a landmark in Toronto and certainly worth checking out as you wander around this great city.
Make sure you cross the street to get some great pictures.

reviews.title: Made me look twice
text: I was on my way to find some lunch in the middle of the snow when I looked at this building and had to stop because I didn't understood it at firsrt.
It's a nice view. Odd actually

reviews.title: A chance encounter
text: Very reminiscent of the same named building in New York. Very photogenic when you can avoid the new construction.

reviews.title: Love this building
text: One of my favourite buildings. Near the bottom of Yonge Street and on the East side of Berczy Park there is a clever mural facing the park, a bar and apartments in the building. Itâ€™s a great building, unusual in shape and far nicer to look at than a lot of the concrete and glass in downtown Toronto.

reviews.title: Not a bad spot at all
text: Building was pretty cool, pretty close to other things we wanted to see and wasn't crowded at all. We did walk past it and not realize at first though

reviews.title: Cool building
text: The construction around it continues as people have mentioned already but this is a pretty cool building to check out and get a picture of if youâ€™re in the area.

reviews.title: Nice quick stop
text: Cool building and a nice quick stop.  Lots of construction going on so pictures are a little difficult but a must stop if you go to St. Lawrence Market.

reviews.title: A must see when in town
text: Love the shape of the building, very quirky. Unfortunately there was some construction going on at the front so our photos donâ€™t do it justice! The mural on the back of the building was very cleverly done. Glad we took the time to go there even though the weather was not great.

reviews.title: The iconic centre of Toronto
text: It's gone through several owners over the years and has often had underwhelming restaurants occupy the ground floor (like the present one which serves mediocre food while blaring out crap music while next to traffic). However, somehow, it feels more like a soulful centre to the city than the CN Tower. It has a charm and iconic aesthetic lacking in most other areas. It just begs for photos and often obliges with Instagrammable imagery.

reviews.title: An Iconic building of Toronto
text: Gooderham building is definitely one of those structures which gives character to a city die to both its shape and history. Located ar downtown Toronto, it's one of the early building which was an important centre of administration. Though the interior is not accessible, one could admire the exterior faÃ§ade. Don't forget to see the back of the building which has gone through a facelift.

reviews.title: Unique
text: i'm really glad this building was kept around. Not only is the shape unusual -- the entire exterior is one-of-a-kind!

reviews.title: Historical beauty
text: It is worth stopping here to enjoy the history of the area and take a photo.  The current flatiron building was built in the 1890s to replace the old 1830s Coffin Block Building.  The New York version was built over 10 years later.  You can look at an old picture of the area on Wikipedia to see how much things have changed which is pretty cool.  If you need a break from shopping and sightseeing there is a nice place to grab a bite there as well.
